citations.narrative:
The licensee acquired one adult male and two adult female fennec foxes for display. The current license does not permit
covered activity with wild or exotic canids.
Licenses authorizing the use of specific species types in subparts D and F are issued based upon successful passing of a
pre-licensing or re-licensing inspection to verify that the licensee is presently equipped and able to provide the appropriate
husbandry and veterinary care needs of the species they possess or will possess for use in covered activity.
The facility must not perform covered activity (such as exhibition or sales) for classes of animals that are not permitted on
their license. If the licensee wishes to perform covered activity with species not included on their license, they must first
apply for and secure a license to include the appropriate species class(es) before using the animals in covered activities
or housing them among animals used in covered activity.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 06/28/2025

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is one adult zebra finch that is observed to be pecked by a few of the six other adult zebra finches housed in the
same primary enclosure. The bird has an area about the size of a nickel on its neck and back where the skin is reddened
and devoid of feathers; there are additional such areas that are smaller on the back of the head, near the right shoulder
and on the mid-back. The licensee was not aware of the bird's condition when pointed out by the inspector.
Failure to make adequate daily observations for animals prevents problems from being noticed in a timely manner and
communicated to the veterinarian to determine the appropriate action, prolonging an animal's pain, distress or discomfort.
The licensee must conduct adequate daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being and ensure
that there is a mechanism for direct and frequent communication to the attending veterinarian regarding timely and
accurate information concerning problems with animal health, behavior and well-being. Additionally, the licensee must
seek consultation with the attending veterinarian for this animal's care and husbandry.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEEKING VETERINARY CARE FOR THIS BIRD BY 10:00AM ON 6/26/2025

The licensee has incomplete and/or inaccurate acquisition records for one adult female Egyptian weasel, two adult female
fennec foxes and one adult male fennec fox. The acquisition records for these animals consist of an incomplete Form
7020 and a copy of an airline shipping certificate that lists "25 weasels" along with the three fennec foxes. The licensee
stated they ordered and picked up only two of these weasels from the airport, and do not know anything about the other
weasels noted on the airline certificate. Neither page of the records lists a name and address for the buyer, and the
species of weasel is not noted.
Lack of required acquisition information prevents accurate tracking of animals to ensure their humane use. The licensee
must establish a system of recordkeeping to ensure the creation and maintenance of acquisition and disposition records
which fully and correctly disclose all of the required information for all animals on the inventory, including those born on
premises.
TO BE CORRECTED FROM THE DATE OF THIS INSPECTION ON 6/25/2025

The licensee does not have documentation of the annual review for the facility's Contingency Plan since the plan was
approved and put into place in April, 2024.
The licensee must ensure not only that a Contingency Plan is in place, but also that it is reviewed at least once annually
to ensure it adequately addresses the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section and is still relevant to the facility and
animals. The plan must provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in
the event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee must maintain documentation of the annual review, including
documenting any amendments or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 07/02/2025

Three lop rabbits weighting approximately 2lbs each are housed in a primary enclosure measuring 523.13 square inches;
these animals collectively require a minimum of 648 square inches of floor space (1.5 square feet each).
Failure to provide the minimum floor space results in overcrowding that can cause the animals discomfort and/or distress,
leading to competition for resources, incompatibility, illness or injury. The licensee must ensure that each rabbit housed in
a primary enclosure is provided at least the minimum amount of floor space according to their individual weights and other
factors as described in Part 3, Subpart C, Section 3.53(c); the final amount of floor space must exclude the space taken
up by food and water receptacles.
CORRECTED DURING THIS INSPECTION ON 6/24/2025

There is one adult zebra finch with missing feathers and reddened skin areas that is frequently pecked by the other six
adult zebra finches with which it is housed. When this was pointed out to the licensee, the bird was immediately removed
from the enclosure and placed by itself in another cage nearby with food, water and enrichment.
Housing birds together that are incompatible causes distress for them and can result in animals being denied food, water
and other resources, and lead to illness, injury or even death. The licensee must ensure that birds are not housed with
other animals, including members of the same species, unless they are compatible, do not prevent access to food, water
or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-being of each other.
Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and by actual
observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible.
CORRECTED AT THE TIME OF THIS INSPECTION ON 6/24/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees.

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(ii) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee acquired one adult male and two adult female fennec foxes for display. The current license does not permit 
covered activity with wild or exotic canids.  
Licenses authorizing the use of specific species types in subparts D and F are issued based upon successful passing of a 
pre-licensing or re-licensing inspection to verify that the licensee is presently equipped and able to provide the appropriate 
husbandry and veterinary care needs of the species they possess or will possess for use in covered activity.  
The facility must not perform covered activity (such as exhibition or sales) for classes of animals that are not permitted on 
their license. If the licensee wishes to perform covered activity with species not included on their license, they must first 
apply for and secure a license to include the appropriate species class(es) before using the animals in covered activities 
or housing them among animals used in covered activity.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY 06/28/2025 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).

and devoid of feathers; there are additional such areas that are smaller on the back of the head, near the right shoulder 
and on the mid-back. The licensee was not aware of the bird's condition when pointed out by the inspector.  
Failure to make adequate daily observations for animals prevents problems from being noticed in a timely manner and 
communicated to the veterinarian to determine the appropriate action, prolonging an animal's pain, distress or discomfort. 
The licensee must conduct adequate daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being and ensure 
that there is a mechanism for direct and frequent communication to the attending veterinarian regarding timely and 
accurate information concerning problems with animal health, behavior and well-being. Additionally, the licensee must

TO BE CORRECTED BY SEEKING VETERINARY CARE FOR THIS BIRD BY 10:00AM ON 6/26/2025 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors.

The licensee has incomplete and/or inaccurate acquisition records for one adult female Egyptian weasel, two adult female 
fennec foxes and one adult male fennec fox. The acquisition records for these animals consist of an incomplete Form 
7020 and a copy of an airline shipping certificate that lists "25 weasels" along with the three fennec foxes. The licensee

species of weasel is not noted.  
Lack of required acquisition information prevents accurate tracking of animals to ensure their humane use. The licensee 
must establish a system of recordkeeping to ensure the creation and maintenance of acquisition and disposition records 
which fully and correctly disclose all of the required information for all animals on the inventory, including those born on 
premises. 
TO BE CORRECTED FROM THE DATE OF THIS INSPECTION ON 6/25/2025 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The licensee does not have documentation of the annual review for the facility's Contingency Plan since the plan was 
approved and put into place in April, 2024. 
The licensee must ensure not only that a Contingency Plan is in place, but also that it is reviewed at least once annually

documenting any amendments or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 07/02/2025 
3.53(c)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three lop rabbits weighting approximately 2lbs each are housed in a primary enclosure measuring 523.13 square inches; 
these animals collectively require a minimum of 648 square inches of floor space (1.5 square feet each). 
Failure to provide the minimum floor space results in overcrowding that can cause the animals discomfort and/or distress,

CORRECTED DURING THIS INSPECTION ON 6/24/2025 
3.160(b)  Direct
   
Compatibility and separation 
There is one adult zebra finch with missing feathers and reddened skin areas that is frequently pecked by the other six 
adult zebra finches with which it is housed. When this was pointed out to the licensee, the bird was immediately removed 
from the enclosure and placed by itself in another cage nearby with food, water and enrichment.

other animals, including members of the same species, unless they are compatible, do not prevent access to food, water 
or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-being of each other. 
Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and by actual 
observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible. 
CORRECTED AT THE TIME OF THIS INSPECTION ON 6/24/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees.
